Try to only focus on things you can physically feel right now   like  the weight of yourself sitting in your chair  the way your clothes feel  the weird fluids and tensions running through your body  Try to clear out any lingering thoughts on intangible things   don't worry about anything except this exact moment  Allow yourself to slow down   If you can figure out how to defuse a panic attack not be based in reality  Even people who have a great life "on paper" can be diagnosed  just look at Robin Williams et al   You're seeking help  and you started medicating  so that's a step in the right direction  All I can offer is  don't get discouraged if your meds don't help as much as you think they should  Keep working with your doctor to tweak your prescription or try different meds  And friend The only way to fix depression would be to remove the emotion  the hurt    and we need that  The best thing is to find balance    peace    I guarantee you aren't alone   in any of the "weird" things you feel think  or "bad" habits    Procrastination is one of the biggest symptoms of depression  but not really commonly known     Obviously it's good if we do all the things we should every day   but for a lot of us that isn't realistic just yet    Don't try to "fix" everything at once  we are more likely to fail and that is likely to make us get more depressed    Doing like OP and starting with one basic thing and creating a habit is the way to go   then we get the pride of succeeding  the knowledge we CAN succeed  and find it is enjoyable  It makes us feel better about ourselves  even just a little  and can motivate us to take another step    Start with small  easily attainable goals for each day  Even if it is a list that can be completed in 10 minutes   it is still a list of accomplishments to check off  and still is something to reflect on at the end of the day    No Zero Days  look that up online   there are a few write ups about the concept     We don't have to do it all at once   we just need to at least one little thing each day  The rest will follow    Don't worry  there are a TON of us     I feel guilt   not because everything they try to do for recommend you read the book "Why Am I Still Depressed " by Dr  Jim Phelps  My psychiatrist recommended it to me  with the warning that some of the information is a little outdated   It goes over a lot of these issues  such as what very mild cases of hypomania can look like  Many people think they're just having a rare good day  What's significant is that you're having breaks in the depression yet continue to relapse  In contrast  someone with just depression would have one or two major episodes throughout their life  during which they would not experience relief  However  once the depression is over  it's over  Bipolar depression comes and goes   The book also discusses the idea that bipolar disorder and unipolar depression are on a spectrum  and it's possible to not "really" be bipolar but be just bipolar enough that you'd do better on mood stabilizers than antidepressants  Not all mood stabilizers are scary  especially the ones for milder cases  I personally am on Tegretol and Lamictal  and haven't had many side effects other than a little bit of forgetfulness  Nothing more significant than forgetting a word in the middle of a conversation  In contrast  before I took these meds I was suicidal  Definitely worth it   When I was on antidepressants  lexapro  to be specific   I did find them to help enormously in terms of making that awful  empty feeling go away and preventing me from becoming suicidal  However  I did continue to experience mild depression and changes in attitude   for example  being talkative and productive one day  and antisocial and exhausted change it   I'll give a personal anecdote for this  I've always been pretty awkward  I never really knew why  I just though that was how I was supposed to be and there was nothing I could do about it  The more I talked about how awkward I was  the less awkward I became  It shed new light on things I hadn't even considered before  it led to me understanding the root of my awkwardness and how to effectively combat it  It turned from me hating my awkwardness  to me embracing that I was awkward sometimes  but I could improve my social skills and become more outgoing   Introspection can only get you so far in the end  You really need to talk to someone to truly understand how you feel  as an outside opinion can often by the tipping point in the end to understanding yourself  It's a constant nothing   I suppose first you need to understand what makes you unhappy about yourself and actively want to change that  You can't just want other people to fix your life  it won't happen  but they still in that "wait    what day is it again " I agree with myceli yum that it would be important to get checked out by a doctor just in case  But if that does not lead to an insight  I would try a number of experiments if I were you  Try different exercises to see if the nausea occurs no matter what you do  for example what if you just go swimming for a change  Or go for a jog  Or even a walk  Try a much shorter and easier workout and see if you still get nauseous  Try it with a different trainer and without a trainer to see if it is something about your interaction with the trainer that leads to anxiety  Try working out on your own without anyone present  Also try to take the trainer's advice an increase your caloric intake significantly  and see whether that helps  Try different things and keep track of any times when you are not nauseous and figure out what could account for it  Once you find a way to work out without nausea  then you can start from that and see how much you is just a mind fuck  Lolol   Can so relate  I'm too busy living in my imaginary world to participate in reality  It's hard  Sometimes even think why go outside and do something when my fantasy will always be 10x better  To make my point more clear I will give you an example of taking responsibilities for my thoughts and actions and change them bit by bit   Suppose you caught yourself thinking  I am depressed therefore I cannot be successful  my brain is messed up   You will then take a piece of paper and write down the thoughts  Then you will write a counter thought  For example  write "If I want to be successful I have to stop entertaining this belief that I cannot be successful because my brain is messed up  People with that type of beliefs cannot be successful  In fact  I believe that although I have not figured it all out yet  there's a way for me to become better  To have better attitude  To love myself again  And if I keep changing my thoughts deliberately  I will build the necessary mental habits  I will be alright "   At first  it's like forcing yourself to write down things you don't believe in  but over time  trust me  the positive thoughts will become your new normal  i am in the exact same situation  even 10 years  you know that corny cliche saying   when one door closes  another opens   but were too stuck looking at the closed door    i think that applies delusions  Delusions are things that are out of possibility  Something like the government is following you  aliens  conspiracy theories  alternate realities  Those are delusions  Everyone not liking feelings or disappointing you more often than they bring any light into your life  it might be time to let that go   As far as what to do about it  sometimes nothing is best  You don't really have to you are feeling and encourage them to do the same    I subscribed to this sub a long time ago when things were much worse for me  and I mostly avoid posting because I've gotten better over the years  which I mention now because it's important to realize the effect that surrounding yourself with other crushingly depressed people can have on you  Seek out positive elements and do your best to make them a part of your life  now more than ever  Try to smile on a daily basis   even if everything seems wrong  there's always something to look forward to  so set your sights on that  pick yourself up  and keep moving  If you remain static you run the risk of becoming paralyzed by your grief and your fears    Finally  a bit about grieving that I am going to shamelessly steal from another  much older and wiser  redditor     u GSnow   Alright  here goes  I'm old  What that means is that I've survived  so far  and a lot of people I've known and loved did not  I've lost friends  best friends  acquaintances  co workers  grandparents  mom  relatives  teachers  mentors  students  neighbors  and a host of other folks  I have no children  and I can't imagine the pain it must be to lose a child  But here's my two cents    I wish I could say you get used to people dying  I never did  I don't want to  It tears a hole through me whenever somebody I love dies  no matter the circumstances  But I don't want it to "not matter"  I don't want it to be something that just passes  My scars are a testament to the love and the relationship that I had for and with that person  And if the scar is deep  so was the love  So be it  Scars are a testament to life  Scars are a testament that I can love deeply and live deeply and be cut  or even gouged  and that I can heal and continue to live and continue to love  And the scar tissue is stronger than the original flesh ever was  Scars are a testament to life  Scars are only ugly to people who can't see    As for grief  you'll find it comes in waves  When the ship is first wrecked  you're drowning  with wreckage all around you  Everything floating around you reminds you of the beauty and the magnificence of the ship that was  and is no more  And all you can do is float  You find some piece of the wreckage and you hang on for a while  Maybe it's some physical thing  Maybe it's a happy memory or a photograph  Maybe it's a person who is also floating  For a while  all you can do is float  Stay alive    In the beginning  the waves are 100 feet tall and crash over you without mercy  They come 10 seconds apart and don't even give you time to catch your breath  All you can do is hang on and float  After a while  maybe weeks  maybe months  you'll find the waves are still 100 feet tall  but they come further apart  When they come  they still crash all over you and wipe you out  But in between  you can breathe  you can function  You never know what's going to trigger the grief  It might be a song  a picture  a street intersection  the smell of a cup of coffee  It can be just about anything   and the wave comes crashing  But in between waves  there is life     Somewhere down the line  and it's different for everybody  you find that the waves are only 80 feet tall  Or 50 feet tall  And while they still come  they come further apart  You can see them coming  An anniversary  a birthday  or Christmas  or landing at O'Hare  You can see it coming  for the most part  and prepare yourself  And when it washes over you  you know that somehow you will  again  come out the other side  Soaking wet  sputtering  still hanging on to some tiny piece of the wreckage  but you'll come out     Take it from an old guy  The waves never stop coming  and somehow you don't really want them to  But you learn that you'll survive them  And other waves will come  And you'll survive them too  If you're lucky  you'll have lots of scars from lots of loves  And lots of shipwrecks      I seriously just panicked that I'm a day late returning to work    Made me euphorically manic and had me discussing sheep with anyone who would listen for some reason    but it didn't trigger it for long  only smoked the one night   Effects may depend on strain and dose and susceptibility so use with caution   Starting off anything you're going to be the worst at it  You're the one with the least experience of course    I was an absolute shitty athlete  but if you work hard you don't have t be good for people t respect you  I was terrifible  The worst player in the league  and my team still encouraged me to get better and I was an all around liked guy    Don't give up  you'll get better   It is not your fault  What they did is criminal  Love and best wishes your way  3  3  3  You can do it   hugs  And that fantastic  fuzzy feeling you get when they eventually die  from an accident or age  Came here to say this  Also you might have to to try a couple different medications before you find the right one  so if you're not getting better  having side effects  etc  tell your doctor   Congrats      "Too many have had bad side effects"  So I can't get anything anymore  The burden of depression is hard to carry  especially when everybody wants you to pretend you're fine when you're not   I hope you can shed this burden or at least lighten the load you carry by yourself each day   There is no shame in reaching out if you ever need to  I hope your depression is gone or at least eases this year   Remember life has highs and lows  depression mutes the highs and amplifies the lows  but you are important and loved  I vividly remember the morning in 1997 when  after 4 weeks on an SSRI  I woke up feeling     not euphoric  but     normal  fine  okay  No feelings of dread or despair  or wishing I could just sleep forever  There was morning sunlight coming into the room  and I lay there for a bit thinking how nice that was  and realizing that it had been months and months since I had been able to notice how nice the morning sunshine is  I've had recurrences since then  and I've had to adjust my medications numerous times due to side effects or a specific med becoming ineffective for me after a few years  But I've had good psychiatrists who 1   Listened to me and took me seriously whenever I felt there was a problem with my medications  2   Were knowledgeable about a wide range of medication options  and 3   Were flexible and creative with adjusting doses or combining different medications  I talk to a lot of people who went to a general practitioner  or a second rate psychiatrist  who prescribed the latest "breakthrough" drug  or some old standby medication they always prescribed  and then when the results weren't good  the doctor would basically blame the patient  So these people went on suffering terribly with depression under the mistaken belief that "antidepressants don't work for me " Ooh  I could just throttle the quacks who treat their patients that way  if any practitioner tells you you're out of options with medications  or that the side effects you are experiencing are "not typical for this medication"  i e "you are imagining things"   find another doctor  You can feel better  Non chemical strategies such as cognitive behavioral therapy are important  too  and can be very very helpful  but in my experience I couldn't use those tools effectively until my underlying biologically based depression was under control  I wish you luck  Do not give up    You are going to have a good  fulfilling life    Take a shower  wash off the day  Drink a glass of water  Make the room dark  Lie down and close your eyes   Notice the silence  Notice your heart  Still beating  Still fighting  You made it  after all  You made it  another day  And you can make it one more  You're doing just fine   Hugs  ive gone from 50mg to 100mg in bad times recently  and i find myself suicidal every morning   its been about 3 weeks   should i keep going  You should buy a pet that will keep you company and love you    and also finding a girlfriend over time  D good luck hope all works out for you  3 I second what  u leap2 has already said  I used to have extreme panic attacks very often and it has been going for a while  but therapy really helped  Note that therapy doesn't always mean "go take a bunch of pills"  there are many kind of therapies and a lot of them what you could call "talk therapy"    I underwent Cognitive Behaviour therapy and it helped to reduce the intensity and frequency of panic attacks  It also teaches you how to help yourself without the need for distracting yourself  with video games for example   I'm just throwing this one in as an example of non pill taking therapy  I know there are many more but I have no experience with them    So the best thing to do would be to consult with your doctor and take it from there  There is an important distinction that needs to be made here    'Ideas of reference must be distinguished from delusions of reference  which may be similar in content but are held with greater conviction'  13  With the former  but not the latter  the person holding them may have 'the feeling that strangers are talking about him her  but if challenged  acknowledges that the people may be talking about something else'  14  https   en m wikipedia org wiki Ideas of reference and delusions of reference  A delusion is fixed and false and cannot be reasoned through despite evidence to the contrary    I assure you not everyone hates you   and I bet you can find some examples for yourself to counter this  idea  and  feeling   It is a cognitive distortion that can be reasoned through  If you  believe  everyone hates you  you may provide elaborations for your delusion like you are damned or a mastermind villain    I think the gray area or spectrum for this may be if there is a great delay in your ability to reality test    We start wiping stuff out and we begin to lose ourselves    Which makes memory loss during depression even more fun  Nothing I do these days makes me feel any better  I go outside  listen to music for a bit  I feel momentarily alive  Then I come back inside  and I start dissociating again  I think "Oh  if I watch a movie I like  it would motivate me to get going again " Nope  Maybe I feel kind of good for the hour and a half of movie runtime  but then I crash into the ground again  I'm "out of it" practically 24 7  I don't even feel like myself anymore  if that makes sense  I don't even have energy left to contemplate suicide  which I did until fairly recently  I feel like I'm hurtling towards are  You are loved  you are cherished and each day is a new day to start over    Give em hell  friend   I appreciate your post  Thanks  The question "am I delusional or not " can definitely be inadequate for understanding your beliefs  When I'm trying to assess a problematic belief or thought process  I think about it along three axes  each scaled from 1 100   First axis is probability  where 1 is "this is a proven  verifiable thing that is currently happening " and 100 is "this is impossible " Second axis is degree of belief  where 1 is "I do not believe this" and 100 is "I believe this with every fiber of my being " Third axis is degree of distress  where 1 is "this doesn't bother me" and 100 is "this is so upsetting that I'm in a constant state of panic and unable to function "    Very few things are impossible  but some things are so vanishingly improbable as to essentially be the same thing  "I can teleport to Mars this afternoon" can pretty easily be rounded up to a 100  Whereas  say  "the FBI is keeping close personal tabs on me" could span more or less the entire range depending on your political activities     When your second axis doesn't square with the first  there's an issue  and it helps to discuss with a trusted third party    a therapist  a close friend    to try to figure out what's up  If I am 100  convinced that the FBI is following me  but it's objectively unlikely that they'd be so invested in my activities  I want someone to persuade me of that latter part  particular if this belief is really upsetting to me or keeping me from doing things  Which is the third axis     You can also believe in things that you  know  are impossible  which sounds completely contradictory    but human minds are  I believe  and I'm not being facetious with this  that I could speak Russian in an emergency  I have never studied Russian on even the most elementary level  but I believe I could do it in the same way that a mother can lift a car off her baby    fueled by adrenaline and  in my case  an ability to tap into the collective unconscious and draw language from it  Do I  know  this is ridiculous  Yep  Is it  to quote the language of religious discrimination laws  a "sincerely held belief"  Yep  And since it doesn't bother me at all  and isn't dangerous   that should probably be a fourth axis   I don't feel the need to try to reality check my way out of it     Your belief that everyone hates you sounds  using the language of psychology  anyway  more like a cognitive distortion than a delusion  but I think what matters more than the terminology is how you are able to disprove or minimize this belief  and decrease the amount of pain it causes you      Anyway  I hope you feel better  and it is extremely unlikely that everyone hates you     What is IOP   Same thing would happen with my but i'm too scared of being alone to stop messaging or talking to them  I wish life was kinder for the both of us     please don't give up    not substances and overuse them  so it's definitely contributed to the 10lbs I'd gained since mid december   I recently learned that while it's gotten me out of suicidal depression  it had also caused psychosis that I thought was someone else's fault  That someone else had shared their super potent weed induced psychosis  but what I think had actually happened was that I'd hallucinated that  too  So whether the guy hypnotized me to believe it or I hallucinated him doing that  weed's at fault  And that psychosis is behind every time I've been inpatient and at least half of my suicidal episodes   It can make us manic  and with heavy use it tends to bring on depression  although the causality on that is still being investigated    For me  I use it to relax and escape depression  I also prefer it to alcohol  because alcohol makes me depressed but weed leaves me feeling better for awhile  My biggest issues with weed right now are the legal status and implications for employment  I'm on the job market   It still induces some psychotic symptoms if I'm careless  but I've got them extremely well controlled and am no longer afraid of them  I figure any significant changes to my beliefs I'd Long story short  sometimes  when some people use the word "bored" when describing social settings or life in general  it cooouuuld be  very tentative  not projecting  don't jump the gun   that the person is suffering from undiagnosed ADD   Mind you  not the hyperactive part  but the just the deficit part    So  when you couple someone who is naturally introverted with a touch of ADD  you get a person who WANTS all the pleasures of social interaction and WANTS to be involved in the dating game BUT said person also gets frustrated quickly  that's an ADD trait  and finds that the pleasures they can find on their own are easier to come by yet wholy different from the pleasure of social and dating things   As far as depression goes  your words don't suggest that to me  but maybe someone just quit  I am in college rn and I hated high school  if I had to redo it  I wouldve got a GED and enrolled in community college or online college   School was hell for me  so much busywork  sleep deprivation  and the long ass commute  coupled with lack of friends and loneliness   I graduated frm that place and honestly  I barely learned sht there except that I will never enroll my children in public schools   I suggest you see a psychiatrist first tho because they might prescribe you antidepressants  Thanks for posting this  I've had quite a bit of depression since childhood and quitting gluten had one of the largest impacts towards getting better  Other dietary tweaks were made possible afterwards since I had a much clearer mind and body  Increases in good proteins with every meal and a dramatic increase in fats while keeping carbs on the lower end of things has made the blood sugar fluctuations decrease to a minimal amount   Start small would be my advice  Exercise and reading are both excellent and very easy to pick up  You don't necessarily need to hit the gym  Start with a simple bedroom routine just basic movements nothing intense no weights necessary just your body and working on breathing  Meditation also ties in with exercise particularly the breathing exercises  Hell even try going for a walk or hike  Researching programmes and techniques online should get you into the habit of reading  After that pick up a book or comic  if it's been a while re read a favourite just to get you back into the habit  I'd suggest fiction to begin with because non fiction tend to be way more academic   Listening to music is always a good distraction as well  Hanging out with friends and family as well  Has worked for me when I was in a better frame of mind   I've heard woodworking and lego building can be quite relaxing although never tried it personally  This will get buried  but     About 5 years ago  my MIL that I loved dearly died on Dec 7th after a protracted battle with cancer  My FIL was on antidepressants but it just wasn't enough  My MIL had a beloved dog that we bought her a few years prior to her death  We were hoping the dog's loving presence would help her emotionally  and he did  and all of us fell in love with him  After my MIL died  my FIL was so lost  He insisted my husband and I go out with our friends for New Years Eve like we had planned earlier in the Fall  So with misgivings  we went    On New Years Day my husband received a call from his dad  and he could barely understand him because he was crying so much   This is a family of people that don't express emotion  so him sobbing to his son was unprecedented   Turned out their beloved dog suddenly developed seizures within a week's time and died traumatically at the Vet's office in the wee hours of New Years Day   I will never forget standing there in the parking lot of the restaurant  our friends still seated inside  the wind bitterly cold  the crash of the waves from the coast  as my husband and I cried silently  because we didn't want to upset my FIL  The complete emptiness  staring at the too bright sun and hating everything so  so much  What "loving" god could see a reason in taking a grieving husband's last link with his dead wife  It was literally the worst sequence of events in my life  I became a robot and dissociated from my feelings so I could be the rock my husband needed  but I will never forget the overwhelming tide of pain that ensued when I finally opened myself back up   Fast forward to now  my FIL remarried  there was drama initially   both hubs and I adore this woman  they moved to the country and he is HAPPY  He told me last Christmas that he could never have imagined something this good for himself during the darkest  bitterest time of his life    It's like Sam says to Frodo  how can you go on when there's so much hurt  how could the ending be good  Because the heroes of the stories we love had lots of chances of turning back  but they didn't  They kept going    I want you to keep going  It's what your mom would want  You're not alone in your grief  Good things are still ahead   hugs  Mourn and remember her  but don't stop treatment resistant depression  since there are so many different variables in life   That being said  exercise is the single intervention that has had  the greatest effect  on my depression  However Some of the tools that have been useful to me in the context of building life enhancing practices into my life one at a time     daily exercise  at least half of it outdoors    daily meditation and at least weekly group meditation    good diet  emphasizing vegetables  plant proteins  fatty fish  fruits  and fats from nuts avocado olive oil and minimizing sugar  wheat  alcohol  and dairy    weekly therapy     antidepressants    supplements including vitamins  probiotics  fish oil  and rhodiola    novelty at least weekly if possible e g  trying a new activity  going a new place  meeting a new person    creative outlets such as journaling  art  music    social interaction at least weekly e g  hiking with friends  board games with friends  can be combined with novelty     purpose  such as thinking about ways your career is important to the world  planning for a shift to a future career that feels purposeful to you  or engaging in volunteering hobby caregiving that brings you some kind of purpose or deeper meaning  can be combined with social interaction     Together all of these might seem like a giant to do list  and sometimes they feel like that  But I also know that taken all together  they make my life much more enjoyable to experience  By implementing them one at a time and building  they feel much more manageable  The list might not look exactly the same for you  but it might be a starting place    Feel free to PM  I have been living with depression for a long time and am always happy to listen   Have done   still diagnosed as Cyclothymic   Thank you so much for Sertaline if you feel better in the first few days then down after   I'd also like to state that Sertaline is an SSRI  which means that it is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor   It won't magically produce Serotonin  the "happy" neurotransmitter  but the Sertaline will maintain a concentration of Serotonin in the synapse   Once you start feeling consistently better and feel like you have the energy to do so  it is important that you get sunlight  proper sleep  exercise  and eat foods containing tryptophan   This will ensure you maintain a proper supply of serotonin   Since the SSRI prevents the reuptake of serotonin  there is increased opportunity for the serotonin in the synapse to be broken down by enzymes   If the neurotransmitter is broken down  it can't be recycled through reuptake   Medicine provides the alleviation of symptoms  allowing you to improve all aspects of your life   I wish you the best of luck  Its nice to see people that can relate and provide don't want to live when I've lost all my sanity  I don't want to live where no matter how much effort I put in  I'm always thrown aside  It must be the fact I hate partying  drugs  and smoking  Can't think if any other reason  I can't fucking take it anymore  I'm tired of having episodes of hysterically crying every single night  My life has become too painful  I also got temporarily laid off from work because I've been working too much  Everything that could possibly go wrong is going wrong and I literally just want out  Based on my experience as well as my studies in psychology I firmly hearing my neurons communicating with each other  really uncomfortable experience     The best thing you can do is to sleep it off  I slept maybe 15 hours a day for the first few days going cold turkey  Eating sweets and drinking a lot of water also helps    Most of the withdrawal symptoms went away within 1 week for me  but it took 1 month to get rid of the head pulses  No problem  how are feel like I know what you're talking about  The utter hopelessness of  "well  this is me for the rest of my life"  can be soul crushing  even in the good times when you think  "ahh  I feel good today but tomorrow I will be back to my normal  sad  self"   The feeling that the good times are too fleeting and forever waiting for the inevitable downturn  Personally I feel that these thoughts will never ever truly go away  life is just too turbulent to be happy all of the time  In my experience the thought of "That's it I've won  no more depression for me" is a dangerous one as it only works to make the next downturn worse  Therefore it is important to learn as much as you can in the bad times   and   the good  making the conscious effort to gain new insights into yourself   to disgustingly over simplify  recognising what makes you sad  what makes you happy  what kind of thoughts start to enter your mind when you feel yourself on the precipice of no return  what changed in  your life  that brought you out of your episode this time  what changed in  yourself   what happened today that you feel good  how can that be repeated  The list goes on  In short  I don't believe that anyone 'just gets better'  their ability to deal with it does when they are open to adapting their way of thinking      When you say 'stuff' what do you mean  Psuedo normal 'life' stuff  paying bills finding a job building or maintaining relationships  or are their particular extenuating circumstances in your life that would be hard for anyone to deal with  In either case it is not a weakness to feel weak  True strength is found in ones ability to  endure   a trait that I personally hold in a higher regard than many others as it transcends the circumstances of the individual and provides a window into the integrity of their character   Now you talk of not being being able to cope on an evolutionary level  Where I understand your statement and have thought similar things myself  I would argue that the successful evolution is built on two defining traits    1  The ability to adapt   2  The ability to endure  The very fact that you undergo this battle every day  despite the fact  you do not always feel like you're winning shows that on an evolutionary level  you are doing exactly what you need to do    As a sidenote I would say that comparing yourself to others is inherently unhelpful  I e  " x  isn't bothered by  y   so why does  y  bother me so much  I must be a pussy"  and just leads down a road of self perpetuating internal resentment  We are all on this arduous march my friend inebriated and it has shaped a skewed view of things in my head that I'm still trying to chisel out and remedy   Instead of drinking  taking drugs and just in general participating in risky behaviour engaging in new social circles are tremendously important in shaping you as an independent and stable human being  You also get a lot of satisfaction from the process of improving at what you're doing no matter how slow it  is   You WILL meet new and interesting people who WILL get you and WILL want to hang out with you by just going out and participating in things you truly like or are passionate about  Don't look for friends by how they look or if they're popular or whatever  go do something that interests you and talk with people who are interested in the same things as you  it's how you occurrence in depressives  and it's horrible to be in  One thing I'd suggest though is taking something to help you sleep around ten or eleven and getting a full night's rest  keeping to a proper
